domains.name: Information Architecture
domains.description: Organizes and structures content to make it easy for users to navigate and find information. This includes defining hierarchies, navigation systems, and workflows to support user tasks and goals.
criteria: Hierarchy and structure: Content is organized logically with clear paths and grouping.
Navigability: Navigation systems are intuitive and minimize cognitive load.
Taxonomy: Terminology is consistent, understandable, and aligned with user expectations.
Searchability: Systems facilitate quick and accurate content retrieval.
Adaptability: Solutions scale effectively with changes in content or user needs.

domains.name: User Interface Design and Interactivity
domains.description: Focuses on simplicity, ease-of-use, and consistency for all users. It includes accessibility, layout, and responsive design to create intuitive interfaces.
criteria: Accessibility: Best practices are embraced and implemented (within the constraints of the project).
Ease of use: Designs are easy to use by the intended audience on their given surfaces.
Visual appeal: Design work is simple, clean, scannable, and organized in a way that makes information easy to parse.
Standardization: Design system components are used and modifications only made where necessary.
UX writing: All available tools are used to ensure the written content in designs is clear, simple, and follows HHS guidelines.

domains.name: Design Advocacy
domains.description: Encompasses effectively communicating design decisions and advocating for user needs to stakeholders and team members. It ensures user-centered design is supported and implemented.
criteria: Clarity: Design decisions are presented with clear, well-supported reasoning.
Empathy: Advocacy consistently reflects a deep understanding of user needs.
Collaboration: Fosters alignment with stakeholders while maintaining design integrity.
Negotiation: Balances user-centered outcomes with technical and business constraints.
Persuasiveness: Effectively communicates the value and impact of design solutions.

domains.name: User Research
domains.description: Involves gathering insights into user needs, behaviors, and motivations using qualitative and quantitative methods to inform meaningful solutions.
criteria: Methodology: Appropriate research methods are selected and applied effectively.
Execution: Research activities are thorough, ethical, and well-documented.
Analysis: Data is synthesized into actionable insights.
Communication: Findings are presented in a way that influences design and strategy.
Impact: Research directly informs meaningful design improvements.

domains.name: Design Methodology
domains.description: Entails selecting appropriate design methodologies, planning their execution, and adapting as needed. It synthesizes user needs, business goals, and constraints into actionable plans.
criteria: Planning: Clear, actionable plans are created for design initiatives.
Flexibility: Adjustments are made efficiently in response to new information or challenges.
Integration: Plans consider user needs, business goals, and technical constraints.
Iteration: Feedback is incorporated effectively at every stage.
Deliverables: Outputs align with project goals and stakeholder expectations.

domains.name: Business & Product Sense
domains.description: Aligns design decisions with user needs and business goals to ensure the product's success. Balances user value with business outcomes.
criteria: Alignment: Design solutions directly support business and product goals.
Prioritization: Focuses on high-impact design opportunities.
Feasibility: Considers resource and technical constraints in decision-making.
Metrics: Designs are evaluated using relevant success metrics.
Strategy: Contributes to product roadmaps and long-term business objectives.

domains.name: Tool Fluency
domains.description: Covers a designer's ability to effectively use a wide range of tools, including design, prototyping, data analysis, and presentation tools, to enhance collaboration and user value.
criteria: Proficiency: Demonstrates skill with a variety of design tools beyond Figma.
Adaptability: Quickly learns and applies new tools to improve workflows.
Collaboration: Uses tools effectively to share and iterate with cross-functional teams.
Innovation: Employs advanced features and integrations to streamline processes.
Communication: Presents work clearly using appropriate tools for the audience.
